qas.question: What practice did Altan Khan put to an end?

answers.text: the native Mongol practices of shamanism and blood sacrifice

qas.question: Who did Altan Khan persuade to convert to Gelug Buddhism?
What did Altan Khan threaten the Mongol princes and subjects with if they did not convert?
Who did the Mongol princes ask to grant them titles?
Why did the Mongol princes ask for titles?

context: Laird writes that Altan Khan abolished <a0_0>the native Mongol practices of shamanism and blood sacrifice<a0_0/>, while <a1_0>the Mongol princes and subjects<a1_0/> were coerced by Altan to convert to Gelug Buddhism—or face <a2_0>execution<a2_0/> if they persisted in their shamanistic ways. <a4_0>Committed to their religious leader<a4_0/>, Mongol princes began requesting <a3_0>the Dalai Lama<a3_0/> to bestow titles on them, which demonstrated "the unique fusion of religious and political power" wielded by the Dalai Lama, as Laird writes. Kolmaš states that the spiritual and secular Mongol-Tibetan alliance of the 13th century was renewed by this alliance constructed by Altan Khan and Sönam Gyatso. Van Praag writes that this restored the original Mongol patronage of a Tibetan lama and "to this day, Mongolians are among the most devout followers of the Gelugpa and the Dalai Lama." Angela F. Howard writes that this unique relationship not only provided the Dalai Lama and Panchen Lama with religious and political authority in Tibet, but that Altan Khan gained "enormous power among the entire Mongol population."
